It's definitely possible, but as this typically violates the robots.txt 
and terms-of-service of these search engines, it's not an area where we 
want to provide explicit directions.

Our generic recommendations for learning the right crawling 
configuration for custom purposes always apply:

(1) Try the default configuration
(2) Observe carefully how it does not meet your needs, in terms of URLs 
fetched or not, discovered or not, enqueued or not, etc.
(3) Hypothesize the smallest (ideally single) settings adjustment that 
might fix the problem, and try that.
(4) If that doesn't meet your needs, compare the actual results to what 
you thought the change would do (to make sure you understand the 
change), and observe how the crawl still falls short of your needs, and 
repeat from (3).

Also note that websites can ultimately refuse to respond to any traffic, 
if they decide it has an appearance/pattern/volume they don't like, so 
there's no one formula that is sure to work over time. (Even people who 
visit search engines via a regular browser at a high rate of requests 
have been locked out.)

- Gordon @ IA
